xs:annotation.xs:documentation: A name uniquely identifying this artifactory server instance across the network.
If marked, Artifactory never tries to fetch artifacts remotely. Only cached and local artifacts are served.
Determines whether help links are shown in the UI.
The maximum size in megabytes for artifact files uploaded through the web UI. Set to '0' for unlimited size.
The format used for displaying dates. For a detailed explanation see: Joda DateTimeFormat
Add-ons-related configuration.
Mail server-related configuration.
Default (globally used) Bintray credentials configuration.
Security-related configuration used in authentication and authorization.
A set of backup configurations.

A set of locally installed repositories. NOTE! that when using the default global virtual repository (repo) the order of the local repositories resolution is determined by the order they appear in this list.

A set of remote proxied (normally cached) repositories. NOTE! that when using the default global virtual repository (repo) the order of the cache and remote repositories resolution is determined by the order they appear in this list.
A set of virtual repositories aggregating regular local and remote repositories.
A set of reusable proxy definitions. Proxies can be used by remote repositories by associating a proxy definition with a remote repository.
A set of reusable reverse proxy definitions.

Define property sets to group together properties of the same category (e.g. QA). Then, define properties and their respective possible values (e.g. performance:{poor,acceptable,good} and qaStaffComment:[any]). Once property sets and their properties are defined, you can associate them with repositories, in order to be able to easily set, update and search for predefined property values on hosted repository items.

A hard-coded URL prefix used by Artifactory for calculating relative URLs. Use this only if you must override the default URL base (similar to the Servlet context URL - e.g. http://myhost.com/artifactory).
The remote URL of a logo image.
Additional custom text to appear in the page footer.
Define reusable repository storage layouts used for identifying modules (module artifacts and module descriptors).
Configure scheduled remote repository replications.
Configure scheduled local repository replications.

Whether to use time-based version numbers for the name of SNAPSHOTs, or to use a non-unique, self-overriding naming pattern of artifactId-version-SNAPSHOT.type (default), or to respect the deployer settings coming from the Maven client.

Checksum policy determines how Artifactory behaves when a client checksum for a deployed resource is missing or conflicts with the locally calculated checksum (bad checksum). Checking checksums effectively verifies the integrity of the deployed resource. The options are: (1) Verify against client checksums (default) - Until a client has sent a valid checksum for a deployed artifact matching the server's locally calculated checksum, the artifact's checksum is not available and returns 404 (not found). If the client has sent a checksum conflicting with the one calculated on the server a 409 (conflict) is returned until a valid checksum is deployed. (2) Trust server generated checksums - Do not verify against checksums sent by clients and trust the store server's locally calculated checksums. An uploaded artifact is available for consumption immediately, but integrity might be compromised.
A-synchronously calculate YUM repository metadata upon RPM deployment and removal.

The depth, relative to the repository's root folder, where YUM metadata is created. This is useful when your repository contains multiple YUM repositories under parallel hierarchies. For example, if your RPMs are stored under 'fedora/linux/$releasever/$basearch', specify a depth of 4.

A comma-separated list of xml file names containing YUM group component definitions. Artifactory includes the group definitions as part of the calculated YUM metadata, as well as automatically generating a gzipped version of the group files, if required.
The default Debian architecture is "Automatic", to change the Debian architecture to 'Trivial' (which is deprecated) and generate the indices in the root directory, set the Trivial Layout checkbox.
Whether the repository is blacked-out. A blacked-out repository or its local cache do not participate in artifact resolution.
Whether the repository handles release artifacts.
Whether the repository handles snapshot artifacts.

The maximum number of unique snapshots (of the same artifact) to store. Any number of snapshots above the max are automatically removed by age. A value of 0 (the default) indicates no limits on unique snapshots number (thus no automatic cleanup).
Whether the repository should suppress POM consistency checks.

The property sets that you are able to use of items hosted under this repository. As property sets are purely assistive and not enforcing, setting this on a repository only affects the list of predefined properties in the user interface properties tab for items under the repository. You are still be able to attach arbitrary properties to repository items.
A property set usable by this repository.

Allow Unsafe Content and Archive Browsing - Determines whether viewing content (e.g., html files, Javadoc browsing) directly from Artifactory is allowed. Allowing content browsing requires strict content moderation in order to make sure malicious users do not upload content that is used to compromise security. For example, to conduct cross-site scripting attacks.
Repository unique ID.
Textual description of the repository. This description also appears when selecting the repository in the Tree Browser.
Optional notes about this repository.

Comma-separated list of artifact patterns to include when evaluating artifact requests, in the form of x/y/**/z/*. When used, only requests matching one of the include patterns are served. By default all artifacts are included (**/*).
Comma-separated list of artifact patterns to exclude when evaluating artifact requests, in the form of x/y/**/z/*. By default no artifacts are excluded.
Select the layout that the repository should use for storing and identifying modules.
Docker API version.
Force basic authentication credentials in order to use this repository.
Force basic authentication credentials in order to use this repository.
HTTP authentication username.
HTTP authentication password.
Allow credentials of this repository to be used on requests redirected to any other host.
Network timeout in milliseconds to use both for connection establishment and for unanswered requests. Timing out on a network operation is considered as a retrieval failure.
Enable cookie management if the remote repo uses cookies to manage client state.
Enable token (Bearer) based authentication
The local address to be used when creating connections. Useful for specifying the interface to use on systems with multiple network interfaces.
Network proxy reference.
Custom HTTP query parameters that will be automatically included in all remote resource requests. For example: param1=val1&param2=val2&param3=val3
If original query parameters should be included in remote requests
The URL for the remote repository. Currently only HTTP/S URLs are supported.
When marked, only already-cached artifacts are retrieved and fetching remote artifacts is not attempted.
Whether failing to communicate with this repository returns an error to the client that fails the build.

Whether the repository should store cached artifacts locally or not. When not storing artifacts locally, direct repository-to-client streaming is used. This can be useful for multi-server setups over a high-speed LAN, with one Artifactory caching certain data on a central storage and streaming it directly to satellite pass-though Artifactory servers.
When marked, the repository attempts to eagerly fetch the jar in the background each time a POM is requested.
When marked, the repository attempts to eagerly fetch the source jar in the background each time a jar is requested.
The number of seconds to cache artifact look-up results. A value of 0 indicates no caching.

The number of seconds the repository stays in assumed offline state after a connection error. At the end of this time an online check is attempted in order to reset the offline status. A value of 0 means the repository is never assumed offline.
The number of seconds to cache artifact retrieval misses (artifact not found). A value of 0 indicates no caching.

Checksum policy determines how Artifactory behaves when a checksum for a remote resource is missing or conflicts with the locally calculated checksum (bad checksum). Checksum checking effectively verifies the integrity of the remote resource. The options are: 1) Generate if absent (by default) - A bad remote checksum fails the resource request. If, however, a remote checksum could not be found Artifactory automatically generates one. 2) Fail: A bad or missing remote checksum fails the resource request. 3) Ignore and generate: Artifactory locally generates a checksum for both bad or missing remote checksum. Remote resource retrieval never fails, but integrity might be compromised. 4) Pass-thru: Artifactory stores and passes-thorugh all remote checksums including bad ones and locally generates a checksum for a missing remote checksum that cannot be found. Remote resource retrieval never fails, but integrity might be compromised and client-side checksum validation (such as the one performed by Maven) fails.
The number of hours to wait before an artifact is deemed "unused" and eligible for cleanup from the repository. A value of 0 means automatic cleanup of cached artifacts is disabled.
Whether or not the configuration details of this remote repository can be publicly shared with remote clients, such as other Artifactory servers.
Whether to synchronize properties of artifacts retrieved from a remote instance of Artifactory.

Lists the items of remote folders in simple and list browsing. Required for dynamic resolution that depends on remote folder content information, such as remote Ivy version lookups. The remote content is cached according to the value of the 'Retrieval Cache Period'

Select the layout that best matches the layout used by remote repository for storing and identifying modules. Path-mapping takes place if the remote layout is different from the local layout - remote module artifacts and descriptors is stored according to the local repository layout (e.g., Maven 1->Maven 2, or Maven 2->Ivy).
Reject the caching of jar files that are found to be invalid. For example, pseudo jars retrieved behind a "captive portal".
Support remote P2 metadata updates.
Proxy and cache NuGet libraries from the remote repository.
Proxy and cache NuGet libraries from the remote repository.
Proxy and cache Bower libraries from the remote repository.
Proxy and cache CocoaPods libraries from the remote repository.
The URL for the original P2 repository. Currently only HTTP/S URLs are supported.
Content synchronisation to another artifactory repository

If set, artifacts will fail to download if a mismatch is detected between requested and received mimetype according to the list specified in the system properties file under blockedMismatchingMimeTypes. You can override by adding mimetypes to the override list below.
A comma separated list of mime types that will be blocked by this repo if the original request was for a different mime type.
Determines whether artifact requests coming from other Artifactories can be fulfilled by accessing this virtual repository's remote repositories or by only accessing its caches (by default).
A set of local and remote repository references to include in a virtual repository.
A named key-pair to use for automatically signing artifacts.

(1) Discard Active References - Removes repository elements that are declared directly under project or under a profile in the same POM that is activeByDefault. (2)Discard Any References - Removes all repository elements regardless of whether they are included in an active profile or not. (3)Nothing - Does not remove any repository elements declared in the POM.
Configuration for automatic P2 handling
Local repository reference (key).
Configuration for fetching external depenednecies
A set of local and remote P2 repository URLs to aggregate under this virtual repository.
Enable filtering of external dependencies
A set of ant patterns to match for external dependencies.
Remote repo used to cache external dependencies
The pattern to match for external dependency

The context path prefix through which the NuGet feeds are served. For example, the NuGet Gallery feed URL is 'https://nuget.org/api/v2', so the repository URL should be configured as 'https://nuget.org' and the feed context path should be configured as 'api/v2'.

The context path prefix through which NuGet downloads are served. For example, the NuGet Gallery download URL is 'https://nuget.org/api/v2/package', so the repository URL should be configured as 'https://nuget.org' and the download context path should be configured as 'api/v2/package'.
The context path to the remote server's simple index. For example, for 'https://pypi.python.org/' it is 'simple/'
The context path to where packages are stored at the remote server. For example, for 'https://pypi.python.org/' it is 'packages/'

The Bower registry URL to communicate with. Usually should be left as a default for 'https://bower.herokuapp.com' unless the remote is an Artifactory instance of which the value should match the remote repository URL.
The CocoaPods Specs Repo URL to communicate with.
The URL of the target P2 repository. This URL should contain a P2 metadata descriptor (composite, content or artifacts).
Local, remote or virtual repository reference (key).
Proxy Unique ID.
Proxy host name.
Proxy port number.
Proxy username.
Proxy password.
The computer name of this machine (that is connected to the NTLM proxy).
Proxy domain/realm name.
Make this proxy the default for new remote repositories and for internal HTTP requests.
An optional list of newline or comma separated host names to which the proxy may redirect requests. The credentials of the proxy are reused by requests redirected to any of these hosts.
Reverse Proxy Unique ID.
The web server type for this reverse proxy
method to use for reverse proxy
A set of reusable reverse proxy repositories.
Backup Unique ID.
Determines whether this backup is enabled or disabled.
The directory to which backup local repository data as files. The default is $ARTIFACTORY_HOME/backup/[backup_key]
The Cron expression by which backup frequency is determined. For detailed information see: The CronTrigger Tutorial

The maximum number of hours to keep old backups in the destination dir. Marking the "Incremental" checkbox, indicates that backups are incrementally (delta only) written to the same directory: ${backupDir}/current. This "in place" backup type is suitable for file-system based backup support, and cleanup of old backups is inactive in this mode. The default is 168 hours = 7 days.
Determines whether the backup output should be a zip archive or a directory (the default).
A set of repository references to exclude from backup.
Local or remote repository reference (key).
Send email notifications to admin users if errors are encountered during the backup process (requires properly configured email settings and valid email addresses for admin users).
Exclude all builds from the backup.
Automatically exclude new repositories from the backup.
Configuration for the indexer creating Maven indexes downloadable by IDEs.
Determines whether the indexer service is enabled and should be run.
The Cron expression by which indexer frequency is determined to recalculate new Maven indexes on selected repositories. For detailed information see: The CronTrigger Tutorial
A set of repository references to index.
Repository reference (key).
When selected, info about available Add-ons is displayed in the Artifactory user interface. Enabling add-ons info display resets any user-specific info-hiding preference.
A variable used for calculating the path for a user cookie storing their personal add-on info showing preferences.
The activity state of the configuration.
The host name of the mail server.
The mail server port.
The authentication username.
The authentication password.
The "from" address header to use in all outgoing mails. Can be left blank.
A prefix to use for the subject of all outgoing mails.
Determines whether to use transport layer security when connecting to the mail server.
Determines whether to use SSL when connecting to the mail server.
The Artifactory URL to use in all outgoing mails to denote links to Artifactory. Can be left blank.
The default Bintray Credentials that will be used by Artifactory in cases where an Artifactory user doesn't have Bintray credentials defined.
The default Bintray user name that will be used by Artifactory in cases where an Artifactory user doesn't have Bintray credentials defined.
The default Bintray API Key that will be used by Artifactory in cases where an Artifactory user doesn't have Bintray credentials defined.
The maximum number of files that a user is allowed to push to Bintray in a single operation. Set to '0' for unlimited.
Determines whether anonymous access to the repository and the UI is permitted.
Determines whether anonymous users can view build related information.

When marked, Artifactory hides the existence of unauthorized resources by sending a 404 response (not found) to requests for resources that are not accessible by the user. Otherwise, the response implies that the resource exists but is protected - by requesting authentication for anonymous requests (401) or by denying an authenticated request for unauthorized users.
Password policy settings (credentials encryption etc.).
Security settings specific to LDAP.
Security settings specific to LDAP Groups.
Security settings specific to HTTP SSO.
Security settings specific to Atlassian Crowd.
Security settings specific to SAML.
Security settings specific to OAuth.
Security settings specific to GPG signing
User locking policy settings.
Security settings specific to SSH.

Determines the password requirements from users identified to Artifactory from a remote client, such as Maven. The options are: (1) Supported (by default) - Users can authenticate using both secure encrypted passwords or clear-text passwords. (2) Required: Users must authenticate using secure encrypted passwords. Clear-text authentication fails. (3) Unsupported: Only clear-text passwords can be used for authentication.
Password expiration policy.
Whether user can be locked up on incorrect login attempt.
The number of incorrect login attempts that will lock user.
Whether user password can expire.
The number of days for password to get expired.
Whether users should be notified by email about password expiration.

Artifactory trusts incoming requests and reuses the remote user originally set on the request by the SSO of the HTTP server.
This is useful if you want to use existing enterprise SSO integrations, such as the powerful authentication schemes provided by Apache (mod_auth_ldap, mod_auth_ntlm, mod_auth_kerb, etc.).
When Artifactory is deployed as a webapp on Tomcat behind Apache: If using mod_proxy_ajp, ensure to set tomcatAuthentication="false" on the AJP connector. If using mod_jk, ensure to use the "JkEnvVar REMOTE_USER" directive in Apache's configuration.

When automatic user creation is off, authenticated users are not automatically created inside Artifactory. Instead, for every request from an SSO user, the user is temporarily associated with default groups (if such groups are defined), and the permissions for these groups apply. Without auto-user creation, you must manually create the user inside Artifactory to manage user permissions not attached to their default groups.

When automatic user creation is off, authenticated users are not automatically created inside Artifactory. Instead, for every request from a SAML user, the user is temporarily associated with default groups (if such groups are defined), and the permissions for these groups apply. Without auto-user creation, you must manually create the user inside Artifactory to manage user permissions not attached to their default groups.
The name of the HTTP request variable to use for extracting the user identity. Default is: REMOTE_USER.
SSH n stuff
SSH server port number.
Enable security integration with Atlassian Crowd.
The full URL of the Crowd server to use.
The application name configured for Artifactory in Crowd.
The application password configured for Artifactory in Crowd.
The time window, in minutes, in which the session does not need to be revalidated.
If a default proxy definition exists, it is used to pass through to the Crowd Server.

When automatic user creation is off, authenticated users are not automatically created inside Artifactory. Instead, for every request from a Crowd user, the user is temporarily associated with default groups (if such groups are defined), and the permissions for these groups apply. Without auto-user creation, you must manually create the user inside Artifactory to manage user permissions not attached to their default groups.

Specify the SSO custom cookie name. Out-of-the-box Crowd uses the 'crowd.token_key' cookie name for all Crowd-connected applications. You can override the default value with your own cookie name. This is useful in environments with multiple Crowd servers.
Authenticate using credentials instead of the default session, token-based authentication. This is required for use with JIRA User Server.
Enable security integration with SAML.
The identity provider login URL (when you try to login, the service provider redirects to this URL).
The identity provider logout URL (when you try to logout, the service provider redirects to this URL).
The certificate for SAML Authentication. NOTE! that the certificate must contain the public key to allow Artifactory to verify sign-in requests.
SAML service provider name: this is the Artifactory name in the SAML federation.

When automatic user creation is off, authenticated users are not automatically created inside Artifactory. Instead, for every request from a SAML user, the user is temporarily associated with default groups (if such groups are defined), and the permissions for these groups apply. Without auto-user creation, you must manually create the user inside Artifactory to manage user permissions not attached to their default groups.

When automatic user creation is off, authenticated users are not automatically created inside Artifactory. Instead, for every request from a SAML user, the user is temporarily associated with default groups (if such groups are defined), and the permissions for these groups apply. Without auto-user creation, you must manually create the user inside Artifactory to manage user permissions not attached to their default groups.
Auto redirect the login page link to the identity provider URL.
Enable security integration with OAuth.

When automatic user creation is off, authenticated users are not automatically created inside Artifactory. Instead, for every request from a SAML user, the user is temporarily associated with default groups (if such groups are defined), and the permissions for these groups apply. Without auto-user creation, you must manually create the user inside Artifactory to manage user permissions not attached to their default groups.
Persist new users.
Default NPM provider.
Security settings specific to LDAP Groups.
Provider unique name.
Provider type.
Provider type.
Provider id.
Provider secret.
Provider url.
Provider authenticationUrl.
Provider token URL.
Provider basic URL.
Provider domain.
Passphrase for GPG signing.
LDAP setting Unique ID.
Determines whether this LDAP is enabled or disabled.
Location of the LDAP server in the form of: ldap://myserver:myport/dc=sampledomain,dc=com

A DN pattern that can be used to login users directlyto LDAP. This pattern is used for creating a DN string for 'direct' user authentication, where the pattern is relative to the base DN in the LDAP URL. The pattern argument {0} is replaced with the username. This works only if anonymous binding is allowed and a direct user DN can be used, which is not the default case for Active Directory (use User DN search filter instead). Example: uid={0},ou=People
Determines whether users should be auto-created when using LDAP, otherwise they are transient and associated with auto-join groups defined in Artifactory.
An attribute that can be used to map a user's email to a user created automatically in Artifactory.
LDAP group setting search base.
LDAP group setting search base.
The group name attribute.
The group member attribute.
Mark if you want to check the full subtree when searching.
The filter to search for in the group.
The group description.
The group description.
A reference to the LDAP setting to retrieve this group.

An authentication pattern can include either a userDnPattern for "direct" authentication or searchFilter for user "search" (after binding with a manager DN) and then authentication of the found user. The managerDn and managerPassword are not used for "direct" DN authentication.

A filter expression used to search for the user DN used in LDAP authentication. This is an LDAP search filter (as defined in 'RFC 2254') with optional arguments. In this case, the username is the only argument, denoted by '{0}'. Possible examples are: (uid={0}) - this searches for a username match on the attribute. Authentication to LDAP is performed from the DN found, if successful.

Context name to search in, relative to the base DN in the LDAP URL. ex: ou=users With LDAP Group Add-on enabled, it is possible to enter multiple search base entries separated by the '|' sign. ex: ou=internalUsers,ou=hq|ou=externalUsers This parameter is optional.
Enables deep search through the sub tree of the LDAP URL + search base. True by default.
Used only with "search" authentication method. It is the full DN of the user that binds to the LDAP server to perform user searches.
Used only with "search" authentication method. It is the password of the user that binds to the LDAP server to perform the search.
A unique name identifying the property set.
Whether this property set is visible in the properties management user interface, or is intended for internal use.
The list of properties grouped under this property set.
A unique name identifying the property.
Whether the values of the property shall come from a predefined closed list of values.
Whether the property supports multiple values.
A list of predefined values to select from for the property value(s).
The actual value.
Whether or not this value is a default/pre-selected one (multiple choice properties support multiple default values).
A unique name identifying the layout.

(HTML)
The path pattern that matches the storage path of artifacts.
The path pattern is composed of literals (including path separators) and any of the following tokens:
org, orgPath, baseRev, fileIntegRev, folderIntegRev, module, classifier, ext, type.
Token Description Example Value
[org] Identifies the artifact's organization. Equivalent to Ivy's 'organization'. 'org.apache.derby'
[orgPath] Identifies the artifact's organization where dots ('.') are replaced by path separators ('/'). Equivalent to Maven's 'groupId'. 'org/apache/derby'
[module] Identifies the artifact's module. 'hibernate'
[baseRev] Identifies the base revision part of the artifact version, excluding any integration information '2.1.1' which may be part of the full version '2.1.1-SNAPSHOT' or '2.1.1-build.1099'.
[folderItegRev] Identifies the integration revision part used in folder names in the artifact's path, excluding the base revision. 'SNAPSHOT' or 'build.1099' which may be part of the folder name '2.1.1-SNAPSHOT' or '2.1.1-build.1099', respectively.
[fileItegRev] Identifies the integration revision part in the artifact's file name, excluding the base revision. '20110113.145509-8' or 'build.1099' which may be part of the file name '2.1.1-20110113.145509-8' or '2.1.1-build.1099', respectively.
[classifier] Identifies the artifact's classifier. 'sources'
[ext] Identifies the artifact's extension. 'jar'
[type] Identifies the artifact's type. Typically used when the artifact's extension cannot be reused as the artifact's type. 'javadoc' (that can have the 'jar' extension) or 'ivy' (that can have the 'xml' extension).
[customToken<regex>] A custom regex token. Can be used to create a new type of token when the provided defaults don't suffice. '[timestamp<\d{8}>]' a new timestamp custom token that has 8 digits.
For Artifactory to be able to construct meaningful module information the following tokens have to be used at the minimum:
org or orgPath, baseRev and module.

(HTML)

Check this if the repository layout uses separate path patterns for artifacts and descriptors (such as Ivy descriptor files). Otherwise, the artifact path pattern will be used to match descriptors.

The descriptor path pattern matches the storage path of module descriptors and uses the same format as of the artifact path pattern.

Token Description Example Value
[org] Identifies the artifact's organization. Equivalent to Ivy's 'organization'. 'org.apache.derby'
[orgPath] Identifies the artifact's organization where dots ('.') are replaced by path separators ('/'). Equivalent to Maven's 'groupId'. 'org/apache/derby'
[baseRev] Identifies the base revision part of the artifact version, excluding any integration information '2.1.1' which may be part of the full version '2.1.1-SNAPSHOT' or '2.1.1-build.1099'.
[fileItegRev] Identifies the integration revision part in the artifact's file name, excluding the base revision. '20110113.145509-8' or 'build.1099' which may be part of the file name '2.1.1-20110113.145509-8' or '2.1.1-build.1099', respectively.
[folderItegRev] Identifies the integration revision part used in folder names in the artifact's path, excluding the base revision. 'SNAPSHOT' or 'build.1099' which may be part of the folder name '2.1.1-SNAPSHOT' or '2.1.1-build.1099', respectively.
[module] Identifies the artifact's module. 'hibernate'
[classifier] Identifies the artifact's classifier. 'sources'
[ext] Identifies the artifact's extension. 'jar'
[type] Identifies the artifact's type. Typically used when the artifact's extension cannot be reused as the artifact's type. 'javadoc' (that can have the 'jar' extension) or 'ivy' (that can have the 'xml' extension).
[customToken<regex>] A custom regex token. Can be used to create a new type of token when the provided defaults don't suffice. '[timestamp<\d{8}>]' a new timestamp custom token that has 8 digits.
The path pattern matching the storage path of module descriptors. Uses the same format as the artifact path pattern.

A regular expression matching the integration revision string appearing in a folder name as part of the artifact's path. For example, 'SNAPSHOT', in Maven. Note! that you must ensure not to introduce any regexp capturing groups within this expression. If not applicable use '.*'.

A regular expression matching the integration revision string appearing in a file name as part of the artifact's path. For example, 'SNAPSHOT|(?:(?:[0-9]{8}.[0-9]{6})-(?:[0-9]+))', in Maven. Note! that you must ensure not to introduce any regexp capturing groups within this expression. If not applicable use '.*'.
Enable active replication of this repository.
The Cron expression by which replication frequency is determined. For detailed information see: The CronTrigger Tutorial
Delete artifacts and folders that no longer exist in the source repository.
Include metadata properties of files and folders as part of the replication.
A subpath within the source repository to limit replication to.
The replicated repository key.
Network timeout in milliseconds to use for remote file listing query.
The URL of the target local repository on a remote Artifactory server.
Network proxy reference.
Network timeout in milliseconds to use both for connection establishment and for unanswered requests. Timing out on a network operation is considered as a retrieval failure.
HTTP authentication username.
HTTP authentication password.
Replicate additions and modifications as they occur.
GC config.
The Cron expression by which garbage collection frequency is determined. For detailed information see: The CronTrigger Tutorial
Cleanup config.
The Cron expression by which artifacts cleanup frequency is determined. For detailed information see: The CronTrigger Tutorial
Quota management configuration.
Enable control over the size of storage space used for binaries to avoid running out of disk space.

The maximum disk usage allowed by percentage, of the partition containing the binaries folder. Once this limit has been reached, deployments are rejected with a 413 error (request entity too large) and an error message is displayed in the UI (visible to admin users only). With a filesystem storage the partition checked is the one containing the '$ARTIFACTORY_HOME/data/filestore' directory. With a database BLOB storage the partition checked is the one containing the '$ARTIFACTORY_HOME/data/cache' directory.

The maximum warning-level of disk usage, by percentage, of the partition containing the binaries folder. Once this limit is reached a warning is logged and a warning message is displayed in the UI (visible to admin users only).
Enable Black Duck Code Center integration with Artifactory.
Black Duck Code Center server URI.
Black Duck Code Center authentication username.
Black Duck Code Center authentication password.

Network timeout in milliseconds to use both for connection establishment and for unanswered requests. Timing-out on a network operation is considered as a retrieval failure. Defaults to 20000 milliseconds.
Proxy configuration to use for accessing Black Duck Code Center.
Configuration for the system message that can be displayed in the Artifactory UI.
Determines whether the system message is displayed.
Title for the system message.
Color for the system message's title, in rgb format (i.e. #00ec00)
The message that will be displayed
Determines whether the system message is displayed in all pages or just the home page.
Configuration for the ability to download folders from the UI.
Determines whether downloading folders is allowed.
Max allowed size of all uncompressed files under a tree to download in a single request, in MB.
Max allowed number of files to download in a single request.
Maximum number of folder download requests that will be treated concurrently before being queued.
Configuration for the global trashcan repository.
Determines whether trashcan is enabled.
Allow users with delete permission to optionally skip the trash upon deletion.
The maximum number of days to keep deleted artifacts in the trashcan. The default is 30 days.

(HTML)
The download pattern which matches the remote repository tarballs URLs.
The download pattern is composed of literals (including path separators) and placeholders for the following tokens:
userOrg, repo, refName, fileExtension.
Token Description
{0} Identifies the username or organization name.
{1} Identifies the repository name.
{2} Identifies the branch or tag name.
{3} Identifies the file extension to download.
For example, GitHub uses the following pattern to download tarballs: https://github.com/{userOrg}/{repo}/archive/{refName}.{fileExt}
So to be able to download from any repository in GitHub, the composed download pattern should be {0}/{1}/archive/{2}.{3}.
Global replication configuration.
Globally disable the push replication.
Globally disable the pull replication.
